body:
IMO using `.before` and `.after` can almost be considered an anti-pattern at this point. If you're adding systems in the same place, use `.chain`. If you're not, use a system set.

I wouldn't necessarily suggest deprecating / removing `.before` and `.after`... but the docs should make it clear that `.chain` should be preferred unless you _really_ know better.
I heavily agree with @benfrankel on this. This issue is primarily about removing a footgun, but I'm definitely also fine with a PR advocating chain everywhere in general.

How about change the Note for `.after` and `.before` to something like:

Note: If you're adding systems in the same location, it's recommended that you use `.chain`. You can also add a set of systems.  You may want to use `.after` or `.before` for advanced scheduling and perhaps exceptional cases.

Ok, I can change the Note or keep the sentence and add the new one.

> Note: The given set is not implicitly added to the schedule when this system set is added. It is safe, but no dependencies will be created.

I am beginning with Bevy and Rust. So That sentence seems like containing useful information. Would somebody mind to explain it to me or point me to examples or similar concepts, so I could figure it out.

Thanks to this ticket and the comments here, I could understand scheduling better and how to (not) use .after/.before.

@janhohenheim Thanks for taking time. I am thinking about a concise note to describe this and replace it. I am not sure with a few things here.

You say there is a magic tric:

> ```
> struct ThisRunsInUpdate;
> struct ThisRunsInStartup;
> 
> app
>   .configure_sets(Startup, ThisRunsInStartup)
>   .configure_sets(Update, ThisRunsInUpdate);
> 
> // watch closely, here comes a magic trick
> app.configure_sets(
>   Update,
>   ThisRunsInUpdate.before(ThisRunsInStartup)
> );
> ```

And later you explain since they are in different schedules, it will be ignored. The magic trick is, that even though this could seem to work - it just won't work as one may read? Or is the magic trick is something else?
@kivi yeah, the "trick" here is that this looks correct but does absolutely nothing.

I got something (thanks to all participants of this ticket), that could work without example or we could add a simple small example with SetA, SetB or sample code as suggested in earlier comment.

__
Note: If you configure two groups of systems (let's call them 'Set A') in a Schedule, another group referencing `.after` or `.before` (let's call it 'Set B') will not be added automatically.
It's safe and won't cause any problems or errors. But no dependencies are created: Adding Set A does not automatically create any connections or relationships with Set B. They remain independent of each other.
If you're adding systems in the same location, it's **recommended** that you use **`.chain`**. You can also add a set of systems. You may want to use `.after` or `.before` for advanced planning and perhaps exceptional cases.
__

Please double check:
> It is safe, but no dependencies will be created.

I changed it to
> It's safe and won't cause any problems or errors. But no dependencies are created: Adding Set A does not automatically create any connections or relationships with Set B. They remain independent of each other.

The word **_safe_** could be misleading or maybe it's just me.

# Objective

- Fixes #14552 
- Make the current note of `before` and `after` understandable. 
    - > The given set is not implicitly added to the schedule when this system set is added.

## Solution

- Replace note in docs of [`after` and `before`](https://docs.rs/bevy/latest/bevy/ecs/prelude/trait.IntoSystemConfigs.html#method.before) 
- Note of after was removed completely, and links to `before`, because they notes would be identical.
- Also encourage to use `.chain`, which is much simpler and safer to use

## Testing

- Checked the docs after running `cargo doc` and `cargo run -p ci -- lints`
- Are there any parts that need more testing?
  - no need to test, but please review the text. If it is still including the intended message and especially if its understandable.
